message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells points to a terminal bronchiole. Simple cuboidal cells with surrounding smooth muscles are also characteristic of terminal bronchioles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells suggests that the specimen was obtained from a region beyond the cartilaginous rings, i.e. bronchioles. The presence of smooth muscle suggests the specimen was obtained from the terminal bronchiole, which is the most distal non-respiratory bronchiole before the alveoli begin. Simple cuboidal cells are also present in the terminal bronchioles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells suggest that the specimen was obtained from a part of the respiratory system without cartilage and not involved in mucous secretion. Among the options, only the terminal bronchiole fits this description. The presence of simple cuboidal cells with a surrounding layer of smooth muscle further supports this identification.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells indicates that the tissue is not part of the trachea or larger bronchi. The presence of smooth muscle and simple cuboidal cells suggest a terminal bronchiole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells paired with simple cuboidal cells and a surrounding smooth muscle layer suggest that the biopsy sample came from the terminal bronchiole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Terminal bronchioles are characterized by simple cuboidal cells with smooth muscle but no chondrocytes and goblet cells. This is the only option that fits the description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells and the simple cuboidal cells with smooth muscle suggest that the sample was obtained from the terminal bronchiole. Respiratory bronchioles have alveoli and conducting bronchioles have cilia and goblet cells. Main stem bronchus has cartilage rings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells suggests that the sample was not taken from the main stem bronchus or conducting bronchiole. Simple cuboidal cells suggest that the sample was taken from a region that lacks cilia, which rules out respiratory bronchiole. Therefore, the most likely option is terminal bronchiole which contains simple cuboidal cells with a surrounding layer of smooth muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells and the presence of smooth muscle suggest a terminal bronchiole, which is the last part of the conducting airway. Simple cuboidal cells are the predominant cell type lining the terminal bronchiole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of chondrocytes and goblet cells suggests the sample was taken from the terminal bronchiole, which is the smallest airway that lacks cartilage and mucus-producing goblet cells.
